3.description-2: In addition to the hot springs, the area has trails that allow you to explore the surroundings and enjoy the local flora and fauna. It is an ideal activity for those who want to combine wellness and nature in one place.
3.image-alt: Ruinas de Tulor y Pukar√° de Quitor

4.title: Desert Cycling: Explore San Pedro on Two Wheels
4.description-0: Cycling is one of the most fun and ecological ways to explore San Pedro de Atacama and its surroundings. Renting a bike and riding the various trails that crisscross the desert will allow you to discover incredible landscapes at your own pace, while enjoying the outdoors and freedom that this activity offers.
4.description-1: There are several popular routes for cyclists of all levels, from gentle rides that take you to hidden oases and archaeological sites, to more challenging routes that traverse canyons and climb hills, offering spectacular views of the desert and mountains. Some of the most popular destinations for cyclists include the Pukar√° de Quitor, an ancient pre-Columbian fortress, and the Ojo del Salar, a lagoon in the middle of the desert where it is possible to take a dip.
4.description-2: Cycling in San Pedro de Atacama is an experience that combines exercise, adventure and the opportunity to connect with the natural environment in an intimate and respectful way.
4.image-alt: Ruinas de Tulor y Pukar√° de Quitor

consejos-para-los-viajeros.title: Tips for travelers to San Pedro de Atacama
consejos-para-los-viajeros.intro: Traveling to San Pedro de Atacama is an experience that promises to be unforgettable, but to fully enjoy your adventure in this extraordinary destination, it is essential to be well prepared. From pre-planning to the details you should consider during your stay, here are some essential tips that will make your trip safe, comfortable and rewarding.

0.title: Planning and Preparations: What to Bring and When to Visit
0.description-0: San Pedro de Atacama is located in one of the driest areas in the world, so the weather can be extreme. During the day, temperatures can be quite high, while at night it can be cold, especially in the winter months. Therefore, one of the first tips is to pack clothing suitable for these temperature variations. We recommend that you bring light, breathable clothing for the day, along with a good coat for cold nights.
0.description-1: Also, due to the altitude of the region, it is common to experience altitude sickness (soroche) during the first hours or days of your stay. It is important that you rest well upon arrival, avoid intense physical exertion at the beginning, and stay well hydrated. Carrying coca leaves or drinking coca tea, a traditional remedy, can help mitigate symptoms.
0.description-2: As for the best time to visit, San Pedro de Atacama is an attractive destination year-round, but the seasons can influence your experience. Spring (September to November) and fall (March to May) are ideal for those who prefer more moderate temperatures and fewer tourists. Summer (December to February) is the peak season, although you should be prepared for summer rains that can affect some activities. Winter (June to August) offers incredibly clear skies for astronomical observation, but nighttime temperatures can be very low.
0.image-alt: Ruinas de Tulor y Pukar√° de Quitor

1.title: Health and Safety Care: What You Need to Know
1.description-0: Safety and well-being during your trip are fundamental aspects that should not be overlooked. San Pedro de Atacama is a generally safe destination, but it is always important to be aware of your surroundings, especially in crowded or touristy places. We recommend that you bring a basic first aid kit that includes medicines for altitude sickness, painkillers, anti-diarrheals and, of course, sunscreen and insect repellent, essential to protect you from the intense sun and mosquitoes.
1.description-1: The sun in the desert is extremely strong, so it is vital to protect your skin and eyes. Apply broad-spectrum sunscreen with a high factor (SPF 50 or higher) several times a day, and wear sunglasses with UV protection to avoid eye damage. A hat or cap will also be your best ally against the scorching sun.
1.description-2: Water is another crucial aspect. Although you will find drinking water in San Pedro, it is advisable to stay well hydrated and consume at least two liters of water a day, especially if you plan to do outdoor activities. Always carry a reusable water bottle with you to avoid excessive use of plastic and contribute to caring for the environment.
1.description-3: As for safety, although San Pedro is safe, it is advisable not to leave valuables unattended and to always be alert, especially if you decide to explore on your own in more isolated areas. Hiring local guides for tours and excursions not only ensures that you get the most out of the experience, but also ensures your safety on less-traveled routes.
1.image-alt: Ruinas de Tulor y Pukar√° de Quitor

2.title: Food and Dining: Special Care
2.description-0: Trying the local cuisine is part of the travel experience, but it's also important to take some precautions to avoid health problems. Food in San Pedro de Atacama is generally safe and delicious, but if you're not used to certain ingredients or ways of preparation, it might be wise to start with milder dishes and avoid overly spicy or exotic foods in the first few days.
2.description-1: Always remember to wash fruits and vegetables you eat raw well and prefer recommended restaurants and establishments, where food quality and safety are guaranteed. Also, since water can be a risk factor in some regions, it's advisable to consume bottled water or make sure that drinking water is well filtered.
2.description-2: If you have any dietary restrictions or food allergies, let restaurants and tours that include meals know in advance. Many establishments in San Pedro are used to receiving tourists from all over the world and can adapt to your specific needs, but it's best to be safe and communicate your requirements.
2.image-alt: Ruinas de Tulor y Pukar√° de Quitor

3.title: Transportation and Getting Around: Getting Around San Pedro and Surrounding Areas
3.description-0: Getting around San Pedro de Atacama and its surroundings is easy, but it's helpful to know the options available so you can choose the one that best suits your needs. Renting a vehicle is a great option if you want to explore at your own pace and visit less accessible places, such as remote lagoons or hidden valleys. However, it's important to make sure the vehicle is in good condition and equipped for rough terrain, as some routes can be challenging.
3.description-1: Another option is to use guided tour services. These are ideal if you'd rather not worry about driving and would like to learn more about the region from local experts. Tours in San Pedro are usually well organized and will take you to the main points of interest, as well as include transportation, which is convenient and safe.
3.description-2: As for transportation within the town, San Pedro is small and easily walkable. However, you can also rent bicycles or hire taxis for longer distances. We offer transportation services to the main tourist attractions, so getting around will not be a problem.
3.image-alt: Ruinas de Tulor y Pukar√° de Quitor

4.title: Culture and Behavior: Respect for the Local Community and Environment
4.description-0: Finally, one of the most important tips for any traveler is to respect the local culture and environment. San Pedro de Atacama is a place with a rich history and an ancestral culture that deserves to be valued and protected. When interacting with locals, always show respect for their customs and traditions. Learning some basic words in Spanish, such as "please" and "thank you", is a good way to show your appreciation.
4.description-1: Also, since you will be visiting fragile ecosystems and protected areas, it is essential that you practice responsible tourism. Do not leave trash, respect the signs and marked trails, and avoid touching or taking stones, plants or any natural element from the sites you visit. In this way, you will be contributing to the conservation of the Atacama Desert so that future generations can enjoy it as much as you did.
4.image-alt: Ruinas de Tulor y Pukar√° de Quitor

informacion-sobre-la-altitud-y-precaucio.title: Altitude Information and Precautions
informacion-sobre-la-altitud-y-precaucio.intro: A fascinating destination located in the heart of the world's driest desert, San Pedro de Atacama sits at a considerable altitude, which can be a challenge for many travelers. The altitude, coupled with the unique characteristics of the Atacama Desert, requires special preparation and proper knowledge to ensure a safe and enjoyable experience. Below, we offer a complete guide on what you need to know about altitude in San Pedro de Atacama and the precautions you should take to make the most of your visit.

0.title: Understanding Altitude: What It Means and How It Affects Your Body
0.description-0: San Pedro de Atacama is located at about 2,400 meters above sea level, which already represents a challenge for those not accustomed to living or traveling at high altitudes. However, many of the most popular hikes around San Pedro, such as the Geyser del Tatio or the altiplanic lagoons, are at even higher altitudes, exceeding 4,000 meters in some cases. At this altitude, the air is thinner and contains less oxygen, which can affect the normal functioning of the body, especially if you are not acclimatized.
0.description-1: Altitude sickness, or soroche, is a reaction of the body to the lack of oxygen at high altitudes and can manifest with symptoms such as headache, dizziness, fatigue, nausea, and even breathing difficulties. These symptoms can vary in intensity depending on the person, their level of acclimatization, and how quickly they ascend to higher altitudes. It is critical for travelers to understand that altitude sickness does not discriminate by physical condition; Even people in excellent health can experience these symptoms if they do not take the proper precautions.
0.image-alt: Ruinas de Tulor y Pukar√° de Quitor

1.title: Precautions Before and During Your Trip: How to Prevent Altitude Sickness
1.description-0: To minimize the risk of altitude sickness, it is crucial to acclimatize gradually. If possible, spend a couple of days in San Pedro de Atacama before embarking on higher altitude excursions. This will allow your body to slowly adjust to the environmental conditions. During these first few days, avoid strenuous physical activities and get plenty of rest. Listen to your body and allow it to adjust before exploring the highest points
1.description-1: Staying well hydrated is one of the most effective measures to prevent altitude sickness. At high altitudes, the body loses fluids more quickly, which can exacerbate the symptoms of altitude sickness. Drink water frequently, even if you do not feel thirsty, and avoid excessive alcohol or caffeine consumption, as these substances can dehydrate you and worsen symptoms
1.description-2: In addition, many people find it helpful to consume coca leaves or coca tea, which are traditional remedies used in the Andean region to combat the effects of altitude sickness. These products are widely available in San Pedro de Atacama and can be safely consumed to help mitigate mild symptoms of soroch
1.description-3: If you plan to visit high altitude places such as the Tatio Geyser or the altiplanic lagoons, consider consulting with a doctor before your trip, especially if you have any pre-existing medical conditions or if this is your first time traveling to high altitudes. Doctors can prescribe medications such as acetazolamide, which helps prevent and treat altitude sickness. This medication must be taken before beginning the ascent and during the days of stay at altitude to be effective.
1.image-alt: Ruinas de Tulor y Pukar√° de Quitor

2.title: What to Do If You Experience Symptoms of Altitude Sickness
2.description-0: Despite taking all precautions, you may still experience some symptoms of altitude sickness. If you begin to feel unwell, the most important thing is to stop and rest. Avoid continuing to ascend if symptoms persist or worsen. In many cases, resting and drinking plenty of water may be enough to alleviate mild symptoms.
2.description-1: If symptoms do not improve with rest, consider descending to a lower altitude as soon as possible. This is especially important if you experience severe symptoms such as shortness of breath, mental confusion, or vomiting, as these could be indicative of a more serious condition such as high-altitude pulmonary edema (HAPE) or high-altitude cerebral edema (HCE), which require immediate medical attention.
2.description-2: Most tours in San Pedro de Atacama are organized so that tour guides are trained to identify and manage cases of altitude sickness. Don't hesitate to contact your guide if you feel unwell; they are there to help you and will take the necessary measures to ensure your safety. In severe cases, it may be necessary to cancel the tour or seek medical attention, so it is essential that you feel comfortable sharing any discomfort you experience
2.image-alt: Ruinas de Tulor y Pukar√° de Quitor

3.title: Additional Tips: Enjoying Altitude Safely
3.description-0: Finally, to fully enjoy your trip to San Pedro de Atacama and its surroundings, it is important that you respect your own pace. Don‚Äôt rush to complete all the most demanding excursions in the first few days; instead, plan your itinerary so that you alternate days of intense activities with days of rest or visits to places at lower altitude.
3.description-1: Wearing appropriate clothing is also crucial, as temperatures can fluctuate dramatically at altitude, especially at night. Make sure to dress in layers, with a good windbreaker and warm clothing for cold mornings and evenings. This will not only keep you comfortable, but will also help your body regulate its temperature more efficiently.
3.image-alt: Ruinas de Tulor y Pukar√° de Quitor

informacion-sobre-seguridad.title: Safety Information in San Pedro de Atacama
informacion-sobre-seguridad.intro: San Pedro de Atacama is a fascinating and adventurous destination that offers a wide variety of outdoor activities, from desert explorations to volcano excursions, trekking and biking. However, due to the extreme conditions of the region, it is essential to take into account certain safety recommendations to make the most of the experience without taking risks. Below, we present a detailed guide on the safety measures travelers should keep in mind when visiting this extraordinary destination.

0.title: Proper Preparation for the Weather
0.description-0: The weather in San Pedro de Atacama can vary dramatically between day and night. During the day, temperatures are often warm or even hot, but at night, especially in higher areas such as geysers or volcanoes, temperatures can drop dramatically.
0.description-1: Hydration: Given the extreme dryness of the desert, it is essential to drink plenty of water throughout the day. Dehydration is a real risk, especially during physical activities such as trekking or cycling tours. Always carry a bottle of water with you and drink frequently, even if you do not feel thirsty.
0.description-2: Sun protection: Use high-protection sunscreen, sunglasses, and a hat or cap to protect yourself from the intense sun. Sunburn can occur quickly due to high UV radiation.
0.description-3: Appropriate clothing: Dress in layers to adapt to changing temperatures. During the day, wear light, breathable clothing, but be sure to bring a jacket or coat for cold nighttime temperatures.
0.image-alt: Ruinas de Tulor y Pukar√° de Quitor

1.title: Precautions for High Altitude Excursions
1.description-0: Many of the excursions in San Pedro de Atacama, such as visits to the Tatio geysers or climbs of nearby volcanoes, are done at high altitude. Altitude can affect the body in various ways, especially for those who are not used to it.
1.description-1: Altitude sickness: Also known as soroche, this sickness can affect travelers when they are more than 2,500 meters above sea level. Symptoms include headache, nausea, fatigue and shortness of breath. To prevent it, it is advisable to acclimatize gradually, avoiding physical effort the first few days.
1.description-2: Hydrate and rest: Make sure to drink enough water and avoid alcohol before high-altitude excursions. It is also important to rest properly the night before the activity so that your body can better adapt.
1.description-3: Medical consultations: If you have respiratory or cardiac problems, consult a doctor before doing activities at altitude.
1.image-alt: Ruinas de Tulor y Pukar√° de Quitor

2.title: Safety in Adventure Activities
2.description-0: San Pedro de Atacama offers exciting adventure activities such as trekking, biking, and volcano climbing. While these are unforgettable experiences, it is crucial to follow certain guidelines to ensure safety during these activities.
2.description-1: Trekking: For trekking routes, especially those involving long distances or rugged terrain, it is important to wear appropriate footwear, such as hiking boots, and a first aid kit. Always stick to marked trails and never venture out alone without an experienced guide.
2.description-2: Cycling: If you plan to go on bike tours, make sure to always wear a helmet and gloves. Carry basic tools for repairs in case of punctures and check the condition of your bike before each outing. The routes in San Pedro de Atacama can be uneven, with sandy or rocky terrain, so it is important to be aware of changes in the ground.
2.description-3: Volcano climbing: For volcano climbs, such as the Licancabur Volcano, it is essential to have an expert guide and make sure you are in good physical condition. These climbs can be strenuous and are not recommended for people without previous mountaineering experience.
2.image-alt: Ruinas de Tulor y Pukar√° de Quitor

3.title: Safety Measures for Guided Excursions
3.description-0: Many of the excursions in San Pedro de Atacama are conducted with professional guides, which adds an extra level of safety.
3.description-1: Certified guides: Make sure that the tour guides are certified and have experience in the area. Local guides not only know the trails and the best routes, but they are also trained to act in case of emergencies.
3.description-2: Safe vehicles: If the excursions involve transfers in vehicles, such as visits to the Valley of the Moon or the Tatio Geysers, verify that the vehicles are in good condition and have the necessary safety measures. It is recommended that the vehicle has first aid equipment and fire extinguishers.
3.description-3: Travel Insurance: Before traveling, it is highly recommended to have travel insurance that covers medical emergencies, evacuations and adventure activities.
3.image-alt: Ruinas de Tulor y Pukar√° de Quitor

4.title: General Considerations for Personal Safety
4.description-0: Beyond outdoor activities, it's important to take basic personal safety precautions during your stay in San Pedro de Atacama.
4.description-1: Documentation: Always keep your personal documents, such as your passport and credit cards, in a safe place. Consider carrying a copy of your important documents in case of loss.
4.description-2: Cash: Although there are ATMs in San Pedro, not all remote areas accept credit cards, so it's advisable to carry some cash.
4.description-3: Nighttime precautions: Although San Pedro de Atacama is a quiet town, it's advisable to avoid walking alone through the town's streets after nightfall, especially in less-traveled areas.
4.image-alt: Ruinas de Tulor y Pukar√° de Quitor

pueblos-y-comunidades-cercanas.title: Nearby Towns and Communities
pueblos-y-comunidades-cercanas.intro: The vast and enigmatic landscape of the Atacama Desert is not only home to natural wonders, but also a rich cultural heritage that is reflected in the towns and communities surrounding San Pedro de Atacama. Inhabited by descendants of ancient civilizations, these places offer a deep look into the history, traditions, and way of life of the people who have called this arid desert home for centuries. Below, we will explore some of the towns and communities near San Pedro de Atacama that are worth visiting.

0.title: Toconao: The Village of White Stone
0.description-0: Located about 38 kilometers south of San Pedro de Atacama, Toconao is a small town known for its unique architecture built from white volcanic stone, called liparita. As you walk through its narrow streets, you will be amazed by the beauty of its houses and buildings, many of which date back to colonial times. The church of San Lucas, built in the 18th century, is an excellent example of the region's architecture, with a free-standing bell tower that has been declared a National Monument.
0.description-1: Toconao is also a starting point for exploring the nearby Jerez Valley, a green oasis that contrasts with the surrounding desert and where fruits and vegetables are grown. The inhabitants of Toconao are mostly farmers and artisans, and it is common to find markets and shops in the town where local products are sold, including alpaca wool fabrics and items made from volcanic stone.
0.image-alt: Ruinas de Tulor y Pukar√° de Quitor

1.title: Socaire: The Gateway to the Altiplanic Lagoons
1.description-0: Continuing south along the road, you will reach Socaire, a picturesque town located more than 3,200 meters above sea level. This small settlement is known for its pre-Columbian agricultural terraces, where inhabitants traditionally cultivate potatoes, corn, and quinoa, using ancestral techniques that have been passed down from generation to generation.
1.description-1: Socaire is the ideal starting point for visiting the Lagunas Altipl√°nicas, one of the natural jewels of the Atacama Desert. These lagoons, located at an even higher altitude, are home to an astonishing biodiversity, including Andean flamingos and other endemic birds. The community of Socaire is also known for its hospitality; travelers are welcome to try the local cuisine, which includes typical dishes such as lamb casserole and quinoa soup.
1.image-alt: Ruinas de Tulor y Pukar√° de Quitor

2.title: Peine: On the Shores of the Salar de Atacama
2.description-0: Peine is a quiet community located on the shores of the vast Salar de Atacama, approximately 90 kilometers from San Pedro. This town is famous for its ancient irrigation canals and cultivation terraces, which have allowed its inhabitants to farm in one of the most challenging environments on the planet. From Peine, one can observe impressive views of the salt flat and the surrounding mountains, creating a landscape that seems taken from another world.
2.description-1: In Peine, visitors can explore the archaeological ruins that date back to pre-Columbian times, testimony to the ancient civilizations that inhabited the region. In addition, the town offers an excellent opportunity to learn about the traditions and customs of its inhabitants, who are mostly dedicated to agriculture and the breeding of llamas and alpacas.
2.image-alt: Ruinas de Tulor y Pukar√° de Quitor

3.title: Machuca: A High Altitude Refuge
3.description-0: About 50 kilometers northeast of San Pedro de Atacama, on the road to the famous Tatio Geysers, lies the small town of Machuca. This settlement, located more than 4,000 meters above sea level, is an impressive example of human adaptation to extreme conditions. With a permanent population of only a few families, Machuca is a testament to the resilience of Andean communities.
3.description-1: The town is known for its picturesque adobe church and thatched roofs that contrast with the arid landscape. Visitors can enjoy an authentic experience by tasting local products such as goat cheese empanadas and llama meat anticuchos. In addition, Machuca is an excellent place to observe local wildlife, including llamas, vicu√±as, and waterfowl that inhabit the nearby wetlands.
3.image-alt: Ruinas de Tulor y Pukar√° de Quitor

4.title: Caspana: A Valley of History and Tradition
4.description-0: Caspana is another of the towns near San Pedro de Atacama that stands out for its beauty and cultural richness. Located in a fertile valley, Caspana is famous for its terraced agricultural lands that date back to time immemorial, used for growing corn, potatoes, and other vegetables. Caspana's houses, built of stone and roofed with mud and straw, retain an architectural style that reflects the influence of ancient Atacame√±os civilizations.
4.description-1: In addition to its stunning agricultural landscape, Caspana is known for its dedication to preserving ancestral traditions. Visitors can participate in local festivities, which include music, dance, and traditional rituals that have endured over the centuries. Caspana is a place where the past and present intertwine, offering an unforgettable cultural experience.
4.image-alt: Ruinas de Tulor y Pukar√° de Quitor

como-llegar.title: How to get to San Pedro de Atacama
como-llegar.intro: San Pedro de Atacama is a small town in the Atacama Desert in northern Chile, famous for its arid landscapes, salt flats, geysers and starry skies. Below are the most common options for getting to this remote destination:

0.title: 1. Arrive by plane
0.description: The quickest and most common way to get to San Pedro de Atacama is to fly from Chile's capital, Santiago, to the city of Calama, which has the closest airport to San Pedro de Atacama.
0.text:
Step-by-step by plane:
Flights from Santiago (SCL) to Calama (CJC): There are daily flights operated by airlines such as LATAM, Sky Airline, and Jetsmart. The direct flight takes approximately 2 hours and 15 minutes, making it the fastest way to travel the 1,200 kilometers that separate Santiago from Calama. It is advisable to book flights in advance, as prices may vary depending on the season.
From Calama Airport to San Pedro de Atacama: Calama's El Loa International Airport is located approximately 100 km from San Pedro de Atacama.
There are several transfer options:
Shared transfer: Several companies offer direct transfer services from the airport to San Pedro de Atacama. These services run frequently, especially when flights arrive. The journey takes approximately 1 hour and 30 minutes.
Private transfer: If you prefer greater comfort or are traveling in a group, you can book a private transfer. This option allows for greater flexibility in timing and a more direct trip.
Renting a car: Several car rental companies are available at Calama Airport. If you choose this option, you can enjoy more freedom to explore the region at your own pace. The road between Calama and San Pedro de Atacama (Route 23) is in good condition and relatively easy to navigate, although you should be prepared to drive in desert areas with little traffic.

1.title: 2. Arriving by bus
1.description: Another option is to travel by bus, a cheaper alternative but considerably slower, since the distances in the north of Chile are long.
1.text:
From Santiago to San Pedro de Atacama:
Duration:
The journey between Santiago and San Pedro de Atacama by bus takes between 22 and 24 hours.
Bus companies: Several companies offer this service, such as Turbus, Pullman Bus and Expreso Norte. Most of these buses have semi-cama or cama seats, ideal for long trips.
Stops along the way: Buses make stops in cities such as La Serena, Copiap√≥, and Antofagasta, allowing you to rest and stretch your legs before continuing.
From other cities in northern Chile:
From Antofagasta: The trip from Antofagasta takes approximately 6 hours by bus. The routes are frequented by several local companies, and departures are usually regular.
From Iquique: The trip from Iquique to San Pedro de Atacama takes around 8 hours.
From Arica: The trip from Arica takes between 9 and 10 hours. In all cases, it is advisable to buy tickets in advance, especially during high season, and to make sure the bus has amenities such as air conditioning and bathrooms.

2.title: 3. Arriving by car
2.description: If you prefer more independence and flexibility, renting a car or driving from your starting point can be a good option. Traveling by car allows you to explore the desert at your own pace, stopping at places less accessible to conventional tourists.
2.text:
From Calama to San Pedro de Atacama:
Distance and time: The distance between Calama and San Pedro is approximately 100 km, and the trip takes about 1 hour and 30 minutes along Route 23.
Road conditions: The road is in good condition, paved and signposted. However, since you'll be driving in a desert environment, it's important to be prepared for possible temperature fluctuations and to bring enough water and fuel.
Gas Stations: Make sure to fill up your gas tank before you leave Calama, as there are no gas stations along the way or in San Pedro de Atacama, and you'll only be able to refuel in Calama or a few nearby points.
From Santiago or Southern Chile:
Distance and Time: The distance between Santiago and San Pedro de Atacama is about 1,600 km. Driving from Santiago is an adventure that can take between 20 and 24 hours, depending
on your pace of travel and the stops you make.
Recommended Routes: The most common route is Route 5 (Pan-American Highway) north, which will take you through cities like La Serena, Copiap√≥, Antofagasta, and finally Calama. From Calama, you'll take Route 23 to San Pedro.
Recommendations: If you decide to travel by car from Santiago, it's a good idea to plan stops to rest and enjoy other tourist spots in northern Chile. Remember to bring basic spare parts, as gas stations can be quite far apart, and temperatures in the desert can vary considerably between day and night.
Additional Recommendations:
Altitude: San Pedro de Atacama is at an altitude of 2,400 meters above sea level, so some people may experience altitude sickness. If you are planning to do activities in even higher areas, such as the Tatio Geysers (4,320 m), we recommend acclimatizing in San Pedro before going to these areas.
Climate: The climate in San Pedro de Atacama is desert, with hot days and cold nights. In summer, daytime temperatures can exceed 30¬∞C, while in winter nights can be very cold, with temperatures below zero. Bring appropriate clothing for both temperature extremes.
Tours and activities: Once in San Pedro de Atacama, there are a wide variety of tours available to explore the region, such as visits to the Moon and Death Valleys, the Salar de Atacama, the Tatio Geysers, the Altiplanic Lagoons, among many others. You can book shared or private tours with Turismochiletours, where we offer different packages and experiences.
Conclusion
San Pedro de Atacama is a destination worth visiting for its natural and cultural wealth. Whether you choose to fly, travel by bus or drive on your own, each option has its own charm and challenges. The important thing is to plan the trip well, considering the transfer time and the conditions of the place to ensure a pleasant experience in this wonderful corner of the Chilean desert.

our-history.title: Our History | Turismochiletours
our-history.description: Discover the history of Turismochiletours, a company dedicated to offering unique and memorable experiences in San Pedro de Atacama. From our humble beginnings to becoming one of the leading tour operators in the region, we have been committed to excellence and customer satisfaction.

hero.title: Our Story
hero.description1: Turismochiletours was born from the dream of a group of young professionals passionate about showing the world the beauty and cultural richness of Northern Chile, especially in one of the most magical and enigmatic places on the planet: San Pedro de Atacama and its surroundings. From the beginning, our goal has been more than just guiding visitors; we want to be the architects of unforgettable experiences, weaving each tour with the history, nature and culture of this incredible corner of the world.
hero.description2: The idea begins during a walk under the stars in the Atacama Desert, where the purity of the night sky reflected the aspirations of a team of young people who wanted to share this majesty with the rest of the world. With years of experience in the tourism sector, we realized that there was an opportunity to offer something more than just tours. We wanted to provide an authentic connection with the local environment and culture, and so, Turismochiletours began its journey.

section1.title1: Our Philosophy: More than Just Guiding
section1.description1: From our first day, we understood that traveling is about much more than visiting places; it's about creating lasting memories. As your personal guide, we're committed to making every moment of your trip extraordinary. We'll take you to discover the wonders of Northern Chile, from its vast deserts and salt flats to its ancient cultures and unique crafts. We want you to marvel at the cleanest skies in the world, while making sure that every aspect of your trip is safe, comfortable, and enriching.
section1.description2: At Turismochiletours, safety is a priority. We make sure that all of our vehicles are equipped and sanitized to deal with desert conditions. Our drivers are experienced professionals, and our guides are experts in the region, able to provide you with detailed information and fascinating stories about each place you visit.

section2.title: Our promise: The best experience
section2.description1: For us, the best experience is one in which every detail has been carefully planned so that you only have to worry about enjoying yourself. From the moment you decide to join one of our expeditions, we dedicate our maximum effort to exceed your expectations and make each tour pleasant and memorable.
section2.description2: Today, with a team that shares an unwavering vision and passion, we are honored to be part of your adventures in Northern Chile. We have grown, but our mission remains the same: to offer you not just a trip, but an experience that will remain etched in your memory forever.

sustainability.title: Sustainability | Turismochiletours
sustainability.description: At Turismochiletours, we are committed to preserving the natural and cultural environment of San Pedro de Atacama. We believe that tourism can be a positive force for conservation and the well-being of local communities.

hero.description: At Turismochiletours, we are committed to preserving the natural and cultural environment of San Pedro de Atacama. We believe that tourism can be a positive force for conservation and the well-being of local communities.

our-commitment.title: Our Commitment to the Environment
our-commitment.description: At Turismochiletours, we understand the importance of preserving the fragile ecosystem of the Atacama Desert. We strive to minimize our environmental impact through various sustainable practices that ensure that future generations can enjoy the natural wonders of this unique region.

0.title: Efficient use of resources:
0.description: We reduce water and energy consumption in our daily operations and promote the use of renewable resources.

1.title: Eco-friendly transportation:
1.description: Our fleet of vehicles is equipped with modern technology that reduces carbon emissions. In addition, whenever possible, we promote the use of bicycles and walking to explore the surroundings.

2.title: Waste management:
2.description: We implement a recycling program and encourage the use of biodegradable materials during our tours, ensuring that we leave the smallest possible trace in the environment.

how-you-can-help.title: How you can help
how-you-can-help.description: You too can be part of the change and contribute to more sustainable and responsible tourism. Here are some ways you can help protect the environment and support local communities during your visit to San Pedro de Atacama.

0.title: Respect for nature:
0.description: Respect the signs and marked trails, avoid touching or taking natural elements, and do not leave trash in the places you visit.

1.title: Support the local economy:
1.description: Prefer to buy local products and authentic crafts, and choose restaurants and tourist services that are owned by the community.

2.title: Active participation:
2.description: Learn about the culture and history of the region, interact with local inhabitants in a respectful manner, and be a conscious and responsible traveler.

policies.title: Policies | Turismochiletours
policies.description: At Turismochiletours, we take transparency and respect for our clients, collaborators and the environment very seriously. Below you will find our policies, terms and conditions that ensure a safe and responsible service.

hero.title: Policies and conditions
hero.description: At Turismochiletours, we strive to offer quality service and transparency in all our operations. Learn about our reservation, cancellation and privacy policies to ensure a safe and satisfactory experience in San Pedro de Atacama.

items.0: Reservations must be made at least <bold>72 hours</bold> in advance to ensure tour availability.
items.1: For reservations made less than <bold>72 hours</bold> in advance, please check directly with the executive to check availability.
items.2: Payments must be made at the time of confirming the reservation, either through bank transfer, credit card, debit card or cash payment at the agency.

items.0: Changes or cancellations to reservations must be notified at least <bold>48 hours</bold> in advance to avoid additional charges.
items.1: Outside of this range, <bold>there will be no refund</bold> of the cost of the tour, <bold>unless the passenger presents a medical certificate</bold> (please review "Cancellation due to Medical Problems").
items.2: <bold>Cancellations due to Weather Conditions:</bold> In the event that the excursion must be cancelled due to weather conditions <bold>before the start of the tour</bold>, a <bold>100% refund</bold> of the tour value will be made.
items.3: If a tour is in transit and must be cancelled due to weather events or any inconvenience that occurs during the excursion, a <bold>proportional refund</bold> will be given to what has been made up to the time of cancellation. These exceptional cases will be reviewed directly with the executive to ensure fair and adequate compensation.
items.4: <bold>No Show:</bold> For shared tours, the agency assigns a specific time slot for hotel pickup, which is confirmed at the time of booking. Passengers must be present in the hotel lobby during that time slot. For private tours, a single confirmed pickup time slot is assigned at the time of booking. In both cases, if the passenger is not at the indicated location and time, it will be considered a "no show" and there will be no right to any refund.

items.0: <bold>Within 24 hours or during the tour:</bold> If the passenger presents a medical certificate issued by the Cesfam of San Pedro de Atacama or any valid medical center less than 24 hours before the tour or when the tour is already in transit or being carried out, a <bold>30%</bold> of the tour value will be refunded.
items.1: <bold>Between 48 and 24 hours before the tour:</bold> If the passenger presents a medical certificate in this period, a <bold>70%</bold> of the tour value will be refunded.
items.2: <bold>Within 24 hours before the tour:</bold> If the medical certificate is presented in this period, a <bold>50%</bold> of the tour value will be refunded.

items.0: <bold>Shared Tours:</bold> Transportation services are limited to the <bold>urban radius</bold> of San Pedro de Atacama. Pickups are not made at accommodations outside this radius or at those with difficult access. It is always recommended to <bold>check with the executive</bold> to confirm if your accommodation is within the coverage area and to verify the availability of <bold>pickup and return to your hotel</bold> for the realization of the excursions. This guarantees correct planning and avoids inconveniences.
items.1: <subItem>In the case of accommodations located in the <bold>historic center</bold> of San Pedro de Atacama, it is possible that passengers cannot be dropped off at the door of the hotel, since, by municipal ordinance, several streets in this area are "pedestrian walkways" and do not allow the transit of vehicles. However, the center is small, and every effort will be made to drop you off as close to your accommodation as possible.</subItem>
items.2: <bold>Private Tours:</bold> The restrictions mentioned above <bold>do not apply.</bold> In these cases, transportation is provided to any requested location, ensuring a completely personalized experience for passengers.

items.0: All tours are conducted by certified guides and expert drivers to ensure safety and quality of service.
items.1: Turismochiletours reserves the right to modify or cancel tours for safety reasons, adverse weather conditions, or unforeseen events, without prior notice.

items.0: Mandatory use of seat belts is required in all transportation vehicles provided by the agency.
items.1: Passengers must follow all instructions from guides and drivers during the tour. Turismochiletours is not responsible for accidents caused by failure to comply with safety regulations.

items.0: Excursions in San Pedro de Atacama involve visiting areas at high altitude. Passengers are advised to arrive acclimatized, stay hydrated, and be in adequate physical condition to participate in the activities.
items.1: In case of health emergencies, first aid kits are available in all vehicles. However, oxygen supply is only provided under professional supervision, following Sernatur regulations.

items.0: The tours include catering services with quality products, such as La Franchuter√≠a baguette bread. It is the responsibility of passengers to inform in advance about any dietary restrictions or allergies.
items.1: The agency is not responsible for allergic reactions or problems arising from food consumption if these restrictions are not previously notified.

items.0: Passengers are expected to respect the instructions of the guides and drivers, as well as the natural and cultural environment of San Pedro de Atacama.
items.1: Turismochiletours reserves the right to refuse service or terminate an excursion if a passenger exhibits behavior that puts the safety or enjoyment of other participants at risk.
